Carbon dioxide (CO2) transformation is a hot topic in both fundamental research and industrial application. Transition metal complexes of tunable and definite structure exhibit unique advantage in the study of CO2 reduction. Catalytic transformation of CO2 at metal complex catalyst is a multi-electron and multi-atom involved process. In this regard, the local chemical environment around the metal center (M) is critical to the catalytic activity. Intramolecularly inducing a supporting site/group into the metal complex catalyst enables to synergistically stabilize M-CO2 or M-COOH adducts with the metal center, which always lowers the energy barrier and/or alters transformation route. Some typical strategies had been applied to design such metal complex catalysts for photo- and/or electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. In this review, we are going to review such representative molecular catalysts (based on earth-abundant metals) that contain an intramolecular supporting site to assist the metal center for efficient photo- and/or electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. According to the structural and functional features of the catalysts, three types of catalyst containing an intramolecular supporting site are summarized. In the first type, one of metal atoms in binuclear complex acts as an intramolecular supporting site to synergistically work with another metal atom for catalytic CO2 reduction. In the second type, hydrogen bond (HD) donor group (such as amide or phenol groups) at secondary coordination sphere acts as an intramolecular supporting site to stabilize M-CO2 adduct via an intramolecular hydrogen bond. In the third type, cis-coordination atoms in several cis-cobalt-complexes function as an intramolecular supporting site in photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The structural characteristics, catalytic performances, and mechanisms of the typical examples in these three types are reviewed. Abbreviations BIH 1,3-dimethyl-2-phenylbenzimidazoline D electron donor DMC 1,8-dimethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane DMF N, N-dimethylformamide GC glassy carbon HD hydrogen donor M metal center n. a. no data available NHE normal hydrogen electrode PET photoinduced electron transfer PS photosensitizer SUS stainless steel TEA triethylamine TEOA triethanolamine THF tetrahydrofuran TOF turnover frequency TON turnover number TPP tetraphenylporphyrin 1 Introduction Carbon dioxide (CO2) is an ideal feedstock for C1-chemical production. Utilization of CO2 in a green and sustainable way can resolve some of the environmental issues caused by CO2 emissions [1–10]. Since chemical inertness of carbon dioxide, the catalytic transformation of CO2 is a challenging task. In addition, CO2 can be reduced to various products (CO, HCOOH, CH3OH, CH4, etc.) via different catalytic pathways. In the most of cases, protons reduction (H2 production) is an accompanying competing reaction in CO2 reduction systems. Therefore, the development of CO2 reduction catalysts with high activity and selectivity is always a hot issue in both fundamental research and industrial practices [11–20]. Transition metal complexes of tunable and definite chemical structure have been extensively studied as CO2 reduction catalysts in photo- and/or electrocatalytic systems [1,6,11,21-25]. The findings helped chemists to fundamentally understand CO2 catalytic transformation at metal center. In this endeavor, numerous transition metals (FeII/III, CoII, NiII, MnII, ReI, RuII, IrIII, etc.) supported by various organic ligands, such as porphyrin, salen (N,N’-ethylenebis(salicylideneiminato), cyclam (1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane), polypyridines and their derivatives, etc., have been synthesized and successfully applied in CO2 reduction systems [11–20]. Based on these model complexes, chemists understand more and deeper on CO2 catalytic transformation at metal centers. More and more efficient molecular CO2 reduction catalysts have been rationally designed and reported [1,6,11,26-28]. CO2 reduction by metal complex catalysts is realized by two different methods, photocatalysis and electrocatalysis. No matter which methods applied, the generation of active catalytic species, usually the reduced metal center of the catalyst, is the key step for the next catalysis (Scheme 1 ). The major difference between the photocatalysis and electrocatalysis is the way of the generation of reduced catalyst. Different from electrocatalysis that the catalyst direct obtaining electron from electrode, the catalyst in photocatalysis undergoes the first reduction via photoinduced electron transfer (PET) from the excited photosensitizer (PS*). In a typical homogeneous photocatalytic CO2 reduction system, at least three components, a photosensitizer (PS), a catalyst, and an electron donor, should be contained [14]. The homogeneous photocatalysis undergoes three steps. First, the PS is excited by visible light to generate excited electrons of high potential. A PET from PS* to the catalyst occurs in the next step. This is a one-electron transfer process, an oxidized PS+• and a reduced catalyst (this reduction mainly occurs at the metal center) M−• generate. Next, the PS+• recovers to PS via receiving an electron from the electron donor. Therefore, whether the redox potentials between catalyst, PS, and electron donor is matched is a key consideration in photocatalysis. The CO2 reduction by metal complex catalysts occurs at the metal center (M). The reduced metal center M (via an electrochemical or photochemical process discussed above) in the molecular catalyst exhibits nucleophilicity to activate and fixate neutral CO2 molecules (Scheme 1) [1,6,11]. The processes of CO2 reduction involve multi-bond cleavage and formation, and are more complicated than the competing proton reduction reaction (2H+→H2) [29–36]. In most cases, CO or formate, two-electron (2e−) reduction products, are the main products in homogeneous CO2 reduction systems. Typically, three activation modes are proposed [13]. The M at its low-valent state direct binds i) C atom, ii) O atom, or iii) break C=O bond of CO2, and forms two kinds of adduct, M-COO or M-OCO. The M-COO) or M-OCO adduct tends to produce CO or formate, respectively. In the most of reported homogeneous systems, CO is the most common reduction production in either photocatalysis or electrocatalysis. In this case, the M-COO adduct is protonated to form M-COOH species. The M-COOH reacts with another proton to release CO and H2O, and the catalyst finally recovers to its initial state. In this cycle, the nucleophilic metal center attacks the C atom in CO2 to form a M-CO2 adduct, which makes one of the oxygen atoms bind to CO2 basic (O−). It is better to stabilize this basic O atom by an acidic atom or site. In homogeneous systems, the metal center in another catalyst or an additional metal cation is proposed to act as a Lewis acid to support this basic O atom (Scheme 1) [16, 37]. Local chemical environment nearby catalytic center always plays a critical role on catalysis. This is well established in either natural enzymes or artificial synthetic catalysts [37–47]. For example, carbon monoxide dehydrogenase (CODH) ([MoCu]-CODH, [NiFe]-CODH) for reversible CO oxidation and hydrogenases ([FeFe]-hydrogenase and [NiFe]-hydrogenase) for reversible protons reduction bear a binuclear structure in their active centers [38–44]. The two metals synergistically work in catalysis. For example, CODH activate CO2 through a “push-pull’ mechanism between two metal atoms in CODH, where one metal center coordinates to CO2 at the carbon atom as a Lewis base, and another metal center binds to CO2 at the oxygen atom as a Lewis acid. The synergistic effect between two metal atoms boosts the catalytic activity of CODH. These are inspiration of synthetic binuclear catalysts. The metal atom activates and binds CO2 is referred to the catalytic center, while another metal atom in binuclear catalyst functions as an intramolecular assistant to stabilize M-COO* species, which is referred to an intramolecular supporting site. Recently, several excellent Reviews focusing on molecular catalysts containing particular metals or particular types of the molecular catalysts for catalytic CO2 reduction [11–18]. The catalysts structures, performances, and mechanisms, as well as development history are well-reviewed in these Reviews. However, there is still no a specific Review focusing on the molecular CO2 reduction catalysts those contain an intramolecular supporting site. This site plays positive role during CO2 catalytic transformation at metal center. Based on a survey of the studies on this topic in the past decade, we summarized three types of such molecular catalysts according to structural and functional features (Scheme 2 ). The first type is molecular binuclear catalyst. The second metal atom in such catalyst function as an intramolecular supporting site to synergistically work with the first metal atom for CO2 catalytic transformation. The second type is molecular catalyst containing H-bond donor groups at its secondary coordination sphere. These groups as an intramolecular supporting site stabilize M-CO2 or M-COOH adducts with the metal center during CO2 transformation. The third type is molecular metal complex of cis-coordination structure. The cis-atom as an intramolecular supporting site participates CO2 transformation at metal center. In this review, we pay attention to the molecular Co, Fe, Ni catalysts containing an intramolecular supporting site, the structural characteristics, catalytic performances, and mechanisms of these three typical models are reviewed and discussed. 2 Binuclear catalysts Early in the 1970s, C. Floriani et al. found alkali and alkaline earth metal cations, such as Na+, K+ and Li+, can act as a Lewis acid to enhance CO2 fixation and transformation at metal complexes [48–50]. They found molecular CO2 can be fixated by a bimetallic [Co(salen)M] (salen = N,N’-ethylenebis(salicylideneiminato) ligand, M = Na+, K+, Li+) complex. In 1978, they reported the definite structure of the [Co(salen)CO2M] adduct by revealing a X-ray single crystal obtained from the reaction of the [Co(pr-salen)K] (RC1) complex with CO2 in a THF solution [49]. The X-ray crystal structure of the [Co(pr-salen)K(CO2)2(THF)] adduct (RC1a, Scheme 3 ) shows that CO2 bonds as a bent molecule to cobalt through a Co-C σ bond, while the two oxygen atoms in CO2 are held by potassium ions; both metals, Co and K, participate to stabilize CO2 (Scheme 3). Interestingly, it was found that the binding of CO2 by the [Co(salen)Na] bimetallic complex was partially prevented in the presence of dicyclohexano-18-crown-6 in a THF solution, due to its high affinity for alkali cations. This finding indicates that the bimetallic [Co(salen)M] type complex works not only in the solid state but also in solution. In 1988, Fujita and coworkers reported a crystal structure of two Co-macrocycle complexes stabilizing a COOH moiety obtained from the reaction of CoIL (L = [14]diene) species (one-electron reduced RC11, Scheme 8) with CO2 in CH3CN or DMF solution [51]. The two cobalt atoms bind to the carbon and oxygen atoms of CO2 to form a Co-C(OH)-O-Co bridge between the two RC11 moieties (RC11a in Scheme 8). This structure shows the synergism of the two cobalt centers to fixate CO2; however, this was achieved by two separated cobalt complexes. Similar results were also confirmed by J.-M. Savéant et al. and T. Kojima et al. using different complexes [52–62]. Inspired by these pioneering studies, recently, molecular binuclear catalysts have been synthesized for CO2 reduction. By designing suitable ligands and regulating the distance between two metals, several classical models of binuclear cobalt, iron, and nickel complexes were reported by Lu, Robert, Naruta and other groups [26-28,51,63-68]. The two metal centers in binuclear catalysts function in tandem as a nucleophilic site to attack the C atom and an electrophilic site to bind the basic O atom of CO2. The two metals can be identical or different. These model complexes exhibited obvious enhancements to the CO2 reduction rate in comparison to its mononuclear analogue under photocatalytic conditions. In 2017, T.-B. Lu's group reported a novel binuclear cobalt complex, RC2, as a molecular catalyst for highly efficient photocatalytic CO2-to-CO conversion [26]. Two Co ions in RC2 are supported by a bi-N4 ligand, and one of the Co binds a -OH (Scheme 4 ). The RC2 is capable of fast absorption and fixation of CO2 within its cavity. This may account for the high selectivity (98%) of CO production even in an aqueous solution (Table 2). The photocatalytic system is composed of CO2-saturated CH3CN/H2O solution by using RC2 as a catalyst, [Ru(phen)3](PF6)2 as a PS (PS1, Scheme 6), and triethanolamine (TEOA) as a sacrificial electron donor. The system produced CO with a turnover number of 16896 and a selectivity of 98%. In contrast, the monomer RC3 system under the same conditions produced CO with a TON of only 1600 and a selectivity of 85%, which are far less than those of the binuclear system. Mechanism studies based on DFT calculations revealed that the two cobalts in RC2 work synergistically for CO2 transformation. As shown in Scheme 5 , RC2 first fixes a CO2 to form a carbonate-bridged complex [CoIICoII(CO3 2−)]2+ (RC2a). RC2a undergoes a PCET process to make [CoIICoI(CO3H−)]2+ (RC2b). Next, RC2b is protonated and loses a H2O to make [CoIICoI(CO2)]3+ (RC2c). RC2c undergoes an intramolecular two-electron reduction to give RC2d via a transition state TS1-1 in which two cobalts synergistically bind a CO2 moiety. After the second PCET process, RC2d is reduced to form [CoIICoII(COOH)]3+ (RC2e). Finally, two cobalt centers synergistically cleave the C-OH bond via a transition state TS2-1, namely, one Co binds to CO and another Co binds to OH. The as-generated [CoII(OH)CoII(CO)]3+ (RC2f) releases CO to regenerate RC2. The energy barriers of CO2 reduction and C-OH cleavage by RC2 are much lower than those by monomer RC3, demonstrating the advantage of two cobalt synergy. Lu et al. further synthesized a heterometallic binuclear complex RC4 (Scheme 4) by replacing one cobalt in RC2 with a zinc atom [27]. This [CoZn] catalyst, RC4, achieved a TON up to 65000 and TOF of 1.8 s−1 of CO production under the same photocatalytic conditions (Table 2). These were 4, 19, and 45-fold higher than the values of corresponding [CoCo] (RC2), [ZnZn] (RC5) and monomer RC3 complexes, respectively. DFT calculations demonstrated that the heterometallic RC4 has a much lower energy barrier for CO2 reduction and C-OH cleavage in comparison to RC2. Another heterometallic [CoZn] complex RC6 (Scheme 4) reported by Z. Chen et al in 2021 [69]. Two metal atoms of RC6 were coordinated with the ligand Hbpbp (2,6-Bis{[bis(2-pyridylmethyl)amino]methyl}-4-tert-butylphenol), in which two moieties are linked a phenolic hydroxyl group. At the optimal condition, TONCO and selectivity reached 6680 and 98%, respectively (Table 2). Photocatalytic experiments and DFT calculation indicated CO2 coordination is more likely to be the rate-limiting step instead of C-O cleavage. Synergistic effect between two heteronuclear also account for the robust photocatalytic efficiency. Robert and Lau et al. reported several CoII-polypyridine complexes as catalysts for photocatalytic CO2 reduction [28]. These cobalt complexes showed high activity and selectivity of CO production. For example, the CoII-quaterpyridine (RC8) achieved CO production of 2660 turnovers and 98% selectivity in a homogeneous CH3CN/TEOA solution containing Ru(bpy)3 2+ (PS1) as a PS and BIH (1,3-dimethyl-2-phenyl-2,3-dihydro-1H-benzo[d]imidazole) as a sacrificial electron donor (Table 2) [70]. Recently, they covalently linked two CoII-quaterpyridine moieties by a dimethylxanthene bridge to synthesize abinuclear cobalt complex RC7 for photocatalytic CO2 reduction (Scheme 4). Interestingly, the main reduction products, CO or formate, can be controlled. Formate with up to 97% selectivity and 821 turnovers can be obtained in a basic CH3CN solution (Table 2). In contrast, CO with 99% selectivity and 829 turnovers can be obtained in the system containing phenol (Table 2). This indicates there are two different catalytic pathways. As shown in Scheme 7 , both pathways begin with the same CO2 adduct RC7b consisting of CO2 sandwiched between two cobalt atoms. The two Co atoms synergistically bind C and the basic O atom of CO2. In acidic conditions, the O atom is stabilized by one Co, which is effectively protonated (RC7d) and subsequently cleaves the C-O bond to release CO as a product. In basic conditions, however, the isomerization adduct RC7e of the two O atoms binding to two Co atoms is protonated at the basic C atom to release formate. In 2022, D. E. Polyansky et al. introduced the parent complex of RC11 (Scheme 8 ) into a photocatalytic CO2 reduction system as photocatalyst [71]. Two RC11 molecules are bridged by a CO2 molecule to form the bimetallic intermediate (RC11b) confirmed by X-ray crystal structure, which is different from the structure proposed by Fujita et al [51]. In this photocatalytic system, the bimetallic pathway can lower energy barriers compared to the mononuclear pathway, resulting in the conversion of CO2-to-CO more feasible in kinetically. The result reveals the further process of RC11 for CO2 reduction through binuclear mechanism without pre-linked between two molecular catalysts. Y. Naruta et al. synthesized a series of binuclear Fe-complexes, RC12-RC19 (Scheme 9 ), based on the Fe-porphyrin monomer for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction [72–74]. They found that the distances between the Fe-Fe core and the substituents on the porphyrin rings significantly affected the catalytic activity. The model complex RC12 of two [FeTPP] (TPP = tetraphenylporphyrin and derivatives) moieties at the ortho-position demonstrated a high CO2-to-CO conversion activity in comparison to the RC18 complex of two [FeTPP] moieties at the meta-position and monomer [FeTPP]. In such binuclear structures, the synergy of two Fe atoms operates via a “Push-Pull” mechanism to stabilize and cleave CO2, namely, one Fe0 acts as a Lewis base to push an electron pair to the bound CO2 and another Fe atom acts as a Lewis acid to pull C-O bond cleavage to afford CO. The distance between the two metal centers is therefore an important parameter for synergistic catalysis. The distance between the two Fe atoms in RC12 was estimated in the range 3.4-4.0 Å, which is suitable to support the linear CO2 molecule of 2.32 Å length. However, the Fe-Fe distance of ca. 10.9 Å in RC18 is too large to synergistically stabilize the CO2 molecule. The overpotential η for CO2 reduction of these binuclear complexes can be tuned by inducing different substituents on the porphyrin ring; inducing electron-withdrawing groups leads to a lower η value. Very recently, a binuclear Fe-complex RC19 (Scheme 9) formed by linking two Fe-porphyrin using urea was immobilized onto carbon nanotubes for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction in an aqueous solution. The RC19 system gave an exceptional turnover frequency (10 s−1) and a high Faraday efficiency (90%) for CO production (Table 1 ), which are higher than those of TOF 2.7 s−1 and FE 35% obtained from the analogue monomer system, further demonstrating the advantage of the binuclear catalyst in heterogenous electrocatalysis. In 1988, J.-P. Collin et al. first reported a binuclear Ni-complex (RC20, Scheme 10 ) for electrocatalytic CO2 reduction [75]. RC20 is composed of two Ni(cyclam)2+ moieties linked by a rigid C-C bond. However, this binuclear complex did not show better performance on CO2 transformation in comparison to its monomer Ni(cyclam)2+ complex. K. Mochizuki reported another analogue binuclear Ni-cyclam complex RC21 of four methyl groups near linkage [76]. This complex exhibited high activity and selectivity of CO2 reduction in a photocatalytic system. The amount of CO production (1230 μL) from the RC21 system was significantly higher than that from the monomer system (195 μL). The author proposed that four axial methyl groups in RC21 prevent the axial coordination of water to the nickel atom, which improves the selectivity of CO2 reduction. However, the existing synergy between the two Ni atoms of RC21 for CO2 transformation was unexplored. Furthermore, T.-B. Lu et al. linked two Ni(cyclam)2+ moieties by a flexible diethylbenzene linkage to make RC22 and RC23 (Scheme 10) [77]. The RC22 of two Ni(cyclam)2+ in face-to-face position showed excellent activity for electrocatalytic reduction of CO2 to CO. A Faraday efficiency of 95% and TOF of 190 s−1 were achieved (Table 1), which were significantly higher than those of RC23 (FE = 25%, TOF = 4.2 s−1) and the monomer RC24 (FE = 62%, TOF = 5.0 s−1). In electrocatalysis (Scheme 11 ), the [NiIINiII] core of RC22 is reduced to NiINiI (RC22a) and subsequently binds with a CO2 to yield a [NiINiI(CO2)]2+ adduct (RC22b). The CO2 in RC22b undergoes intramolecular 2e− reduction to produce [NiIIINiI(COO2−)]2+ (RC22c) via a transition state (TS1-1), stabilizing COO between two Ni atoms using through-space interactions. RC22c is protonated and then cleaves the C-OH bond with the assistance of H3O+ to give [NiIINiII(CO)]4+ (RC22e). The CO is released from RC22e to regenerate RC22. The calculated energy barrier of the rate-determining step in the catalytic cycle of RC22 (8.6 kcal mol−1) is lower than that of the monomer RC24 (11.7 kcal mol−1) due to synergistic stabilizing of CO2 between two Ni atoms. Different from the “Push-Pull” mechanism between two metal atoms for CO2 reduction, the iron atom of RC25 can adjust the charge density of nickel atom to enhance the catalytic activity of CO2 reduction [78]. While, it is not the case for all binuclear metal complexes with synergistic effect between two metal atoms. Two cobalt centers in RC9 (Scheme 4)work independently, without synergistic effect.[79] Although the separation of two centers is 5.7651(2) Å, the flexible structure of RC9 makes two cobalt centers rotate arbitrarily, resulting in inappropriate positions and directions. Our group reported a photocatalytic system composing RC10 (Scheme 4) as a catalyst [80]. At the optimal experiment condition, the photocatalytic efficiency of RC10 was 721 turnover number based on molecular concentration. While the activity of RC10 and its mononuclear analogue present negligible difference. Because of the rigid structure of RC10, the separation of Co-Co (14.77 Å) is too large to produce synergistic effect for CO2 reduction. 3 H-bond donor group bearing catalysts The introduction of H-bond donor groups, such as amide and hydroxyl groups, in the second-coordination sphere is another strategy to position an intramolecular supporting site in a molecular catalyst [81–103]. Different from afore-mentioned strategies of using metal atoms as an intramolecular supporting site, in these kinds of catalysts, the H atom in H-bond donor groups prepositioned in the ligand synergistically stabilizes bound CO2 with a metal center by forming an intramolecular H-bond. [NiII(cyclam)]2+ complex RC34 (Scheme 12 ) is an active catalyst of CO2 reduction in both photo- and electrocatalytic systems [81,84,86]. The one-electron reduced [NiI(cyclam)]+ is the active species to bind CO2 and form a [Ni(cyclam)(CO2)]+ adduct. The amine protons in the cyclam ligand stabilize the CO2 adduct by forming a H-bond with an O atom of CO2, which was proposed by J.-P Sauvage et al. first and recently studied by C. P. Kubiak and S. Ye. Kubiak found that partial or complete substitution of four amine protons in [Ni(cyclam)]2+ with methyl groups (RC35, RC36) leads to a dramatic decrease or loss of the electrocatalytic activity of CO2 reduction [84,86]. DFT calculations revealed that [NiI(cyclam)]+ has a more favorable CO2 binding energy than [NiI(DMC)]+ (a one-electron reduced species of RC35, DMC = 1,8-Dimethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane). The CO2 adduct of [NiI(TMC)]+ (a one-electron reduced species of RC36, TMC = 1,4,8,11-Tetramethyl-1,4,8,11-tetraazacyclotetradecane) cannot form. The trans I isomer of Ni(cyclam) gives more favorable CO2 binding energy than the trans III isomer (Scheme 12) due to more protons being available in the trans I isomer for H-bond formation. The same function of amine protons was also found in cobalt macrocycle complexes. E. Fujita investigated the CO2 adduct of cobalt macrocycle RC11 by FT-IR at different temperatures. They confirmed the existence of intramolecular hydrogen bonds between amine protons and nucleophilic O atoms of bound CO2 at the Co center in RC11 at low temperatures [71]. Recently, S. C. Marinescu et al. reported a cobalt macrocycle complex RC37 of a cyclic aminopyridine ligand electrocatalysis of CO2 to CO with high Faraday efficiency (Scheme 13 ) [88]. The chemical environment formed by pendant amines is important to the activity of RC37. By substituting protons in pendant amines with methyl or allyl groups, the electrocatalytic activity of CO2 reduction decreases by at least 2 orders of magnitude. A mechanism involving an intermediate of two amine protons synergistically stabilizing bound CO2 at cobalt center via a CoI-C bond and two O-H intramolecular H-bonds was proposed (Scheme 13). By introducing phenolic hydroxyl groups in an Fe(TPP) catalyst, J.-M. Savéant et al. found that this phenolic hydroxyl-functionalized RC38 exhibited higher activity and lower overpotential in CO2-to-CO electrocatalysis in comparison to Fe(TPP) and analogue methoxyphenyl functionalized RC39 (Scheme 14 ) [83,85,87,92,94]. The electrochemical reduced Fe0-species of RC38 is the active catalyst that binds CO2 and forms an [Fe0(CO2)] adduct. The phenol groups nearby the Fe atom in RC38 play roles of not only supporting the [Fe0(CO2)] adduct via an intramolecular H-bond between the H atom of phenol group and the O atom of bound CO2 but also improving the local proton concentration, which facilities the protonation step of [FeI(CO2 −)] to [FeI(COOH)]. C. J. Chang et al. further investigated the position effect of the H-donor group on the CO2 catalytic activity of an Fe(TPP) electrocatalyst. They incorporated an amide as a H-donor group into Fe(TPP) and precisely positioned it at various distances and orientations to the Fe atom (RC40-RC43, Scheme 14) [94]. Electrocatalysis studies revealed that the catalysts RC40 and RC41 with an amide located at the ortho-position of the porphyrin showed more activity for CO2 reduction; RC41, with a distally located amide group, was more effective for CO2 reduction than RC40 due to enhanced H-bond stabilization of the [Fe0(CO2)] adduct (RC41a). Recently, Z. Halime and A. Aukauloo reported two Fe(TPP) derivatives, RC44 and RC45, containing multi-NH-donor groups in the second coordination sphere (Scheme 14) [95]. In comparison to Fe(TPP), RC44 with four urea groups showed lower overpotential and higher activity for electrocatalytic CO2; however, no enhancement was observed by RC45 with four amide groups. Mechanistic studies revealed that the CO2 binding rate constant of RC44 is an order of magnitude higher than that of RC45 and Fe(TPP). DFT calculation results demonstrated that both RC44 and RC45 form intramolecular hydrogen bonds between NH and the bound CO2 in the Fe(CO2) intermediate. However, RC44 gives stronger N(H)-O hydrogen bonds with a shorter bond distance in the range of 2.738-2.832 Å (RC44a). This is comparable to those observed in the active site of CODH. 4 Cis-complex catalysts As discussed above, catalysts with a planer structure, such as Fe(TPP) and Ni(cyclam), bind CO2 at one of the trans-coordination positions. The H-bond donor groups located at the organic ligands function as an intramolecular supporting site to synergistically stabilize the M-CO2 adduct. Additionally, metal complex catalysts of cis-coordination geometry have been utilized in small organic molecule catalysis, where two cis-coordination sites participate to stabilize the substate molecule [104–106]. Recently, several cis-CoN4 type catalysts RC46-RC49 (Scheme15 ) exhibited high activity and selectivity of CO2-to-CO conversion in photocatalytic systems by using PS3 as a PS and triethylamine (TEA) as a sacrificial electron donor (Table 2 ) [107–110]. The halogen atoms (Cl or Br) at the cis-coordination site were proposed to play an important role in the course of CO2 transformation. Che et al. pointed out that the Cl atom at one of cis-coordination sites in RC46 acts as an intramolecular supporting site [104]. According to the mechanism based on DFT calculations (Scheme 15), the one-electron reduced [CoILCl] (RC46b) as the active species binds CO2 to form [CoI(CO2)LCl] (RC46c). The protonation process from RC46c to RC46d ([Co(COOH)LCl]+) is exothermic (−2.9 kcal mol−1). However, this process is endothermic (+24.1 kcal mol−1) in the absence of a neighboring cis-Cl atom (Scheme 16 ). A favorable hydrogen bond between cis-Cl and H in COOH in RC46d is proposed. Further utilization of RC47 and RC48 (Scheme 17 ) with the same main structure and different cis-coordination atoms (Cl or Br) as catalysts showed different CO production rates at the same photocatalytic conditions, indicating the participation of cis-halogen atoms in the CO2 catalytic transformation [106]. By introduction of an oxygen atom at cis-coordination sites, our group synthesized another cis-CoN4 type catalyst RC49 (Scheme 17) [105]. This catalyst catalyzed CO2 to not only CO but also formate in a photocatalytic system. The presence of water in the system was able to improve formate selectivity. DFT calculations (Scheme 18 ) revealed that the protonated cis-oxygen functions as an intramolecular supporting site to synergistically work with the cobalt center by relaying a proton to [Co(COOH)] to facilitate C-O bond cleavage in CO production (Scheme 18) or delivering a proton to oxygen in [Co(HCOO−)] and finally releasing formic acid. 5 Outlook Catalytic transformation of CO2 at metal center is highly affected by the local chemical environment nearby the metal center. Recently, the importance of the local chemical environment was also confirmed by several nanosemiconductor-based photocatalytic CO2 reduction systems [111–116]. The interfacial chemical environment of II-VI semiconductor quantum dots (QDs) were tuned via ligand modification or self-assembling, the activity and selectivity of CO2 photoreduction by these QD photocatalysts had been obviously improved. Based on this understanding, chemists tried to design and tune the local chemical environment at the metal center and thus pursue higher activity of CO2 reduction by metal complex catalysts. The success on catalysts/systems design and the resulted CO2 reduction enhancement demonstrates the importance of the local chemical environment of the metal center for CO2 reduction. At a molecular point view, inducing an intramolecular site or group as a functional site is one of promising strategies. In the past decade, three types of CO2 reduction molecular catalysts, binuclear catalysts, catalysts containing functional groups at the second coordination sphere, and catalyst of cis-coordination geometry, had been developed for CO2 photo- and/or electrocatalysis. One of common feature of these catalysts is that they have an intramolecular an intramolecular supporting site nearby the metal center, which facilitates CO2 transformation. Although successes on improving CO2 reduction rate/efficiency by these catalysts have been witnessed, challenges still exist. For the binuclear type catalysts, the appropriate distance between two metal atoms is critical to the synergic catalysis between two metals. This needs rational ligand design. Furthermore, binuclear catalyst is the most promising molecular catalysts to realize multi-carbon reduction products, such as ethylene and ethane, generation. For the last two types of catalysts, catalysts containing H-donor group and cis-catalysts, what they both have in common is the presence of a functional group/atom near the metal center. Chemists should consider to explore more types of functional group/atom, and locates them at suitable positions of the ligand. Employing intramolecular interaction between the functional group/atom and M-CO2 adduct, deep reduction products, such as methanol and methane, is expected to realize by homogeneous molecular system. Additionally, more strategies to alter local chemical environment of more efficient CO2 reduction catalysts/systems are encouraged to explore. The relationship between the local chemical environment and catalytic performances are encouraged to clarified not only via calculations but also based on experimental results. Wu Xia received his B.S. degree in Chemistry from Hubei Engineering University, M.S. degree in Organic Chemistry from Hubei University, and PhD degree in Organic Chemistry under the supervision of Professor Feng Wang from Huazhong University of Science and Technology. Currently, he works in Jishou University as a Lecturer. His research interests focus on photocatalytic CO2 reduction. Dr Feng Wang is currently a full professor at Huazhong University of Science and Technology (HUST). He received his B.S. degree in applied chemistry from HUST in 2005 and his Ph.D. from the Technical Institute of Physics and Chemistry, the Chinese Academy of Sciences, under the supervision of Professor Li-Zhu Wu and Professor Chen-Ho Tung in 2013. He worked as a postdoc in Professor Chi-Ming Che's group at the University of Hong Kong in 2013-2016. He has been working on the research on artificial photosynthesis. He has developed a variety of self-assembly systems for photosynthetic H2 production and/or CO2 reduction based on molecular catalysts and quantum dots photocatalysts. He is currently working on the development of novel photofunctional materials and exploring their applications in sensor, self-assembly, photocatalysis, and so on.

coredata.dc:description: Carbon dioxide (CO2) transformation is a hot topic in both fundamental research and industrial application. Transition metal complexes of tunable and definite structure exhibit unique advantage in the study of CO2 reduction. Catalytic transformation of CO2 at metal complex catalyst is a multi-electron and multi-atom involved process. In this regard, the local chemical environment around the metal center (M) is critical to the catalytic activity. Intramolecularly inducing a supporting site/group into the metal complex catalyst enables to synergistically stabilize M-CO2 or M-COOH adducts with the metal center, which always lowers the energy barrier and/or alters transformation route. Some typical strategies had been applied to design such metal complex catalysts for photo- and/or electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. In this review, we are going to review such representative molecular catalysts (based on earth-abundant metals) that contain an intramolecular supporting site to assist the metal center for efficient photo- and/or electrocatalytic CO2 reduction. According to the structural and functional features of the catalysts, three types of catalyst containing an intramolecular supporting site are summarized. In the first type, one of metal atoms in binuclear complex acts as an intramolecular supporting site to synergistically work with another metal atom for catalytic CO2 reduction. In the second type, hydrogen bond (HD) donor group (such as amide or phenol groups) at secondary coordination sphere acts as an intramolecular supporting site to stabilize M-CO2 adduct via an intramolecular hydrogen bond. In the third type, cis-coordination atoms in several cis-cobalt-complexes function as an intramolecular supporting site in photocatalytic CO2 reduction. The structural characteristics, catalytic performances, and mechanisms of the typical examples in these three types are reviewed.
coredata.dc:title: Molecular catalysts design: Intramolecular supporting site assisting to metal center for efficient CO2 photo- and electroreduction
